11.26.21  3:38 am   Is there an easy way to remember which are columns and which are rows. I have to think like 3 seconds everytime i see either name

      those poles on greek buildings are called "greek columns". if you're on stage looking into the audience, think of all the people sitting in the "front row"

      win

      because the world also does things that are much nicer than that. nice enough to be more than worth it. that's one of the ground rules actually

11.26.21  12:32 am   I keep wanting to learn new piano songs, but I can't find the motivation to stick with one for a while. Do you have any advice?

      it looks like you're gonna have to find ones that you like even more. those ones that really rock your world, that you can't live without. the ones that mean everything to you

11.25.21  11:44 pm   do you ever just sing your songs in your everyday life?

      probably whichever one i'm currently working on, because it would be glued into my head during that time

11.25.21  10:25 pm   thoughts on the moon?

      'wow what an empty place' .... 'the days feel like months'

11.25.21  8:47 pm   I've been playing piano for almost a year now but haven't progressed as much as I thought I would. I still enjoy hitting keys in simple rhythms so much it feels like a chore to do anything else. As a self-taught musician how did you go about learning music theory?

     just by continuing to have fun on the instrument, and maybe starting to get into finding what notes and chords some of my favorite songs are using, which can be figured out by playing the instrument, as you're doing

     Thanks for reading this.

      i'm thankful the deisel pump is too big to fit in the hole for a normal car gasoline tank

11.25.21  6:05 pm   do you like fax machines

      i like the name of them. i've never actually used one

11.25.21  3:21 pm   what do you fear about the new song

      nothing. i'm mostly scared of myself

11.25.21  3:11 pm   How do you know when a song is finished? 

      i don't know

11.25.21  2:54 pm   I want to write music for video games, any advice on how to do such a task?

I know video game songs are very different from your songs in some ways but I still thought I'd ask

      just play the game for a while and start making things up

11.25.21  1:33 pm   what's your favorite mode of transportation?

      already being there

11.25.21  10:58 am   what do you want for christmas

      to finish the song video i'm working on

11.25.21  9:56 am   Who is/are your favorite fictional character(s)?

      'somebody' from the phrase 'i wanna be somebody'

11.25.21  8:28 am   I sing for fun (but not in front of anyone because I just started recently) and I keep hearing words like "pitch" and "tuning" being thrown around which I don't really understand, plus idk anything about music theory, so I was wondering how to improve. It also doesn't help that I only get to sing when the house is empty, which is maybe only twice a week. I also really want to play the piano ever since I messed around with it a few times in the past but I don't have access to it now and my parents are pretty discouraging when it comes to music because they think it's useless and will only distract me further and isn't profitable enough to bring food to the table, so I definitely can't convince them to buy one anytime soon, nor do I know a close friend who owns a piano (probably because I don't have many friends). I want to get involved with music but I'm currently studying engineering (which I'm also passionate about), which is extremely hard to handle as it is without bringing music into the picture. I think I spend a good chunk of my waking hours listening to music in the background, but I'm kind of reluctant to explore music theory not only because it's kind of inaccessible but also because once I dig too deep I just become entrenched in it and I don't want to become even more distracted from my studies. The education system in my country also holds this suffocating disdain for anything related to the arts and music, so there aren't many opportunities/resources that I know of. I'm still pretty optimistic about taking up music as a hobby, but the pressure and competition in academics will only increase in the next few years, making it even harder to give time to basically anything else I might be interested in. Anyway, complaining aside, I just need a few tips on how I could build on any crucial skills I might need for playing an instrument or singing because I've had zero training in anything related to music (due to the aforemention ed shitty education system). Also, sorry for making this unnecessarily long (I wanted to give the proper context for my situation). 

      you're going to have to find something to play. basically the only way you can expand your musical/artistic knowledge and skills is by actually 'playing' with things. that may seem like bad news if you feel like you don't have the time or resources. but i can tell you that even people who have 10 times more time and resources than you still feel like it's not enough. so just focus on whatever is within your time and resources, and begin developing a playful attitude within that space as soon as possible. music can be made with spoons if necessary

11.25.21  7:08 am   i think i have a solution to your problem.  if you keep recording the same song and then producing the same video to accompany it, each production cycle will take the same amount of time.  in this way your schedule can become absolutely uniform

      that's not true, i think it would be faster each time. which is much better than staying the same
